Jennings Trophy |rowspan="3" | Fewest goals given up in the regular season | ||rowspan="2"| |rowspan="3" | |- | |- | || |} ==All-Stars== ===NHL First and Second Team All-Stars=== The NHL First and Second Team All-Stars consists of the top players at each position as voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers' Association. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+ Washington Capitals selected to the NHL First and Second Team All-Stars2014–15 Washington Capitals Official Guide, p.272 ! scope="row" | | |1 | |2nd |- ! scope="row" | | |1 | |1st |} ===NHL All-Rookie Team=== The NHL All-Rookie Team consists of the top rookies at each position as voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers' Association. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+ Washington Capitals selected to the NHL All-Rookie Team ! scope="col" |Player ! scope="col" |Position ! scope="col" |Season |- ! scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |- ! scope="row" | | | |} ===All-Star Game selections=== The National Hockey League All-Star Game is a mid-season exhibition game held annually between many of the top players of each season. Thirty-seven All-Star Games have been held since the Washington Capitals entered the league in 1974, with at least one player chosen to represent the Capitals in each year. The All-Star game has not been held in various years: 1979 and 1987 due to the 1979 Challenge Cup and Rendez-vous '87 series between the NHL and the Soviet national team, respectively, 1995, 2005, and 2013 as a result of labor stoppages, and 2006, 2010, and 2014 because of the Winter Olympic Games. Washington has hosted one of the games. The 34th took place at the Capital Centre. * Selected by fan vote * Selected as one of four "last men in" by fan vote * Selected by Commissioner {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Washington Capitals players and coaches selected to the All-Star Game2014–15 Washington Capitals Official Guide, p.275 |- !scope="col" | Game !scope="col" | Year !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" | Position !scope="col" class="unsortable"| References |- ! scope="row" rowspan="5" | 65th |rowspan="5" |2020 | | |rowspan="5" | |- | | |- | | |- | (Did not play) | |- | | |} ===All-Star Game replacement events=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Washington Capitals players and coaches selected to All-Star Game replacement events |- !scope="col" | Event !scope="col" | Year !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" | Position !scope="col" class="unsortable"| References |- !scope="row" | |1979 | (Did not play) | | |- !scope="row" | |1987 | | | |} ==Career achievements== ===Hockey Hall of Fame=== The following is a list of Washington Capitals who have been enshrined in the Hockey Hall of Fame. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Washington Capitals inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame2014–15 Washington Capitals Official Guide, p.274 ! scope="col" |Individual ! scope="col" |Category ! scope="col" |Year inducted ! scope="col" |Years with Capitals in category ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2010 |1989–1992 |, retrieved June 28, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2015 |2008–2009 |, retrieved November 10, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2001 |1979–1989 |, retrieved June 28, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2015 |1996–1998 |, retrieved November 10, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2002 |1982–1993 |, retrieved June 28, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2004 |1983–1989 |, retrieved June 28, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2012 |1997–2002 |, retrieved June 28, 2015 |- ! scope="row" | |Player |2007 |1982–1990 |, retrieved June 28, 2015 |} ===Foster Hewitt Memorial Award=== One member of the Washington Capitals organization has been honored with the Foster Hewitt Memorial Award. The award is presented by the Hockey Hall of Fame to members of the radio and television industry who make outstanding contributions to their profession and the game of ice hockey during their broadcasting career. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Members of the Washington Capitals honored with the Foster Hewitt Memorial Award ! scope="col" |Individual ! scope="col" |Year honored ! scope="col" |Years with Capitals as broadcaster ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" | |2010 |1974–1997 | |} ===Lester Patrick Trophy=== The Lester Patrick Trophy has been presented by the National Hockey League and USA Hockey since 1966 to honor a recipient's contribution to ice hockey in the United States. This list includes all personnel who have ever been employed by the Washington Capitals in any capacity and have also received the Lester Patrick Trophy. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Members of the Washington Capitals honored with the Lester Patrick Trophy ! scope="col" |Individual ! scope="col" |Year honored ! scope="col" |Years with Capitals ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" | | |1996–1998 | |- ! scope="row" | | |1982–1997 | |} ===United States Hockey Hall of Fame=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Members of the Washington Capitals inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame ! scope="col" |Individual ! scope="col" |Year inducted ! scope="col" |Years with Capitals ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" | |2007 |1981–1987 | |- ! scope="row" | |2001 |1983–1989 | |- ! scope="row" | |2010 |1985–1994 | |- ! scope="row" | |2004 |1996–1998 | |- ! scope="row" | |1999 |1982–1993 | |- ! scope="row" | |1996 |1977–1979 | |- ! scope="row" | |2018 |1982–1997 | |- ! scope="row" | |2017 |1997–2002 | |} ===Retired numbers=== The Washington Capitals have retired four of their jersey numbers. Also out of circulation is the number 99 which was retired league-wide for Wayne Gretzky on February 6, 2000. Gretzky did not play for the Capitals during his 20-year NHL career and no Capitals player had ever worn the number 99 prior to its retirement. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Washington Capitals retired numbers2014–15 Washington Capitals Official Guide, p.233 ! scope="col" |Number ! scope="col" |Player ! scope="col" |Position ! scope="col" |Years with Capitals as a player ! scope="col" |Date of retirement ceremony ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" |5 | | |1982–1993 |November 26, 1997 | |- ! scope="row" |7 | | |1974–1981 |November 7, 1981 | |- ! scope="row" |11 | | |1979–1989 |December 28, 2008 | |- ! scope="row" |32 | | |1987–1999 |March 11, 2000 | |} ==Other awards== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+ Washington Capitals who have received non-NHL awards ! scope="col" |Award ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |Description ! scope="col" |Winner ! scope="col" |Season ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" |Charlie Conacher Humanitarian Award |For humanitarian or community service projects | | | |- ! scope="row" |Golden Hockey Stick |Best Czech ice hockey player | | | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="8"|Kharlamov Trophy |rowspan="8"|Most valuable Russian player in NHL |rowspan="8"| | |rowspan="8"| |- | |- | |- | |- | |- | |- | |- | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="3"|Viking Award |rowspan="3"|Most valuable Swedish player in NHL | | |rowspan="3"| |- |rowspan="2"| | |- | |} ==See also== *List of National Hockey League awards ==References== Washington Capitals award
